title: Susie Boniface: Why does our 'friend' America let crash mum use get-out-of-jail card?
text:

What’s the point of an ally who stops you bringing alleged killers to justice?

That’s not friendship. It’s abuse. Between people it’d be reason to never speak again, and between nations it’s cause for complaints to the United Nations Security Council about foreign interference.

But when American Anne Sacoolas was accused of driving the car that knocked Harry Dunn off his motorbike, leaving him with injuries so catastrophic he could not survive, the other half of our “special ­relationship” sheltered her from the consequences.

She invoked immunity as the wife of a US security agent working at an RAF airbase, and caught the first plane out while police were seeking permission to formally ­question her.

As a mum whose 12-year-old son was reportedly in the car with her and witnessed the crash, she may be enduring the nightmares of a guilty conscience. But she has left behind more than one dead 19-year-old – Harry’s family were wounded too, and Sacoolas’s disappearance denies them any chance of healing.

(Image: PA)

When Gary McKinnon and Lauri Love were accused of hacking US state security, long court battles were waged to extradite them. Eventually it was blocked, but only after years of worry. They were not accused of killing anyone, yet the US threatened lifelong jail terms.

The only thing Sacoolas would have to face here is, maybe, a judge and jury. They would consider CCTV footage of her car on the wrong side of the road and any defence she might offer.

The maximum penalty for causing death by dangerous driving is a two-year ban, and a maximum sentence of 14 years if she was found guilty. But with mitigation, good behaviour and parole, she might serve only a year or two, in a peaceful, cushy nick.

With her children educated at boarding school, it would have far less impact on her family than it does on many.

This is the hell from which she is protected, while Harry’s family endure worse.

(Image: Sky News)

That’s the problem with America First – everything else comes second. This is our major international partner. The one we were told that, post-Brexit, we could rely on. If the US was our friend, it would admit that immunity is for government employees at risk of prosecution for doing their jobs – not a get out of jail free card for their families.

Donald Trump likes to say there is no “quid pro quo” He’s right – we get little in return for our friendship. Had the wife of a British spy fled after allegedly killing an American teen, there’d be a Trumpian tweetstorm.

Boris Johnson might vow to “raise" the issue, but our one-sided “friendship” will be maintained at the expense of Harry, his family, and common decency.
description: What’s the point of an ally who stops you bringing alleged killers to justice?
